awd_titl_txt: CAPS: Hybrid Instruction for Equity in Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is an effort to address computing equity in Atlanta Public Schools. The current national effort to deploy computing education in the K-12 space across the United States is focused on in-service teacher professional development. It is an effort to transform teachers who are not otherwise computer science teachers into subject matter experts to teach high school computer science courses. The Constellations Center for Equity in Computing believes that there simply are not enough teachers in production or in-service that can be trained to be effective computer science teachers, especially in schools that are already distressed serving students of color and poor students of all kinds. Expanding the number of course offerings to include quality high school computer science courses, requires a hybrid instructional model where the specialized subject content is delivered on-line and teacher expertise as facilitator and student guide is maximized. This project will use this strategy to provide highly effective hybrid Advanced Placement Computer Science instruction across the traditional high schools in Atlanta Public Schools.  

Constellation Fellows, expert computer science teachers who have experience teaching in high school, will implement Advanced Placement Computer Science courses in the target high schools.  Each high school will designate a teacher who will assist with facilitation in the classroom.  The courses will be delivered online.  Additional courses will be added in subsequent years.  The resident teachers will observe and collaborate with the Fellows to acquire the knowledge and skills to teach the courses in future years. They will also be provided with opportunities for professional development and continued Fellow support so that they can become exemplary high school computer science teachers.  Constellation's hybrid instructional model is an effort to not only transform the infrastructure of computer science education, but to directly address the reality of inequity that disproportionately limits access for students of color and poor students whoever they may be.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The Computing in Atlanta Public Schools (CAPS) Project proposed a comprehensive professional development (PD) model addressing challenges of access and equity in computer science (CS) education at the secondary level. Specifically in the APS system where 72% of the students identify as Black, there was only one high school out of ten that was offering an AP CS course in 2017. The CAPS project aimed to respond to the challenge of insufficient qualified teachers to teach CS by implementing a robust teacher support project. The project obtained CS Instructional Specialists that completed a rigorous onboarding process including completing a module on principles of cognitive and content-focused coaching; a module on the requirements of the Advanced Placement CS Principles (AP CSP) and AP CS A courses; an online PD and curriculum course on both AP CS courses (approximately 60 hrs. total); and a module on cooperative learning and inquiry strategies that serve as equitable platforms for pedagogy in computing courses. The expertise of CS Instructional Specialists is an essential component in the project ensuring the success of the teacher support program.

The CS Instructional Coaches were deployed across 8 APS high schools to build a sustainable CS program in each school with the capacity to offer one or both of the AP CS courses. The CS Instructional Specialists implemented a comprehensive PD plan: 4-day summer workshop tailored to increase CS content knowledge of the AP CS curriculum that would be used in the classroom; 1-day follow-up workshops (2 in the fall, 2 in the spring) customized to address teachers? needs with curriculum planning and implementation; and individualized coaching sessions 1-2 times a week. CS Instructional Specialists facilitated planning sessions using a coaching cycle that integrated classroom video (teachers only) or classroom observation and participation when possible. The planning sessions also served as a way to build CS content knowledge and strengthen equitable pedagogy. Teachers became more aware of social constructs that are barriers for students. For example, the difficulties that exists for female students in a CS class where the majority of students are male can be daunting. The dynamics of a such a class can be turned into a positive environment if the teacher is supported in implementing equitable and inclusive strategies to build a safe environment for all students. The coaching cycle also includes a reflection session where the selection of various student work products anchors discussions on how students are learning and what factors support their achievement. This part of the coaching cycle is important providing teachers the opportunity to reflect and build on their own experiences. It adds to their developmental growth empowering and motivating them to strive for other goals that increases student participation and success in their classroom. Coaching has provided the structural support for teachers to become the best CS teacher they can be for their students, increasing their content knowledge and also building on sound pedagogy to break through challenges that exist in CS education.

The impact on teaching and educational experiences from this project sheds light on the power of CS Instructional Specialists that serve as coaches. Especially for teachers who are new or novice to teaching CS, an instructional specialist or coach can provide the equitable structural support to increase teaching efficacy in both content and pedagogy to support broadening participation in computing education. The CS Instructional Specialists deploying principles of cognitive coaching supports teachers by empowering them to develop content knowledge in a sustainable fashion, and to understand the implementation of equitable and inclusive pedagogy is imperative for successful engagement and achievement for students historically underrepresented in computing. Through coaching, teachers become more confident of their instructional decisions and are more aware of how to engage students, motivate them, and increase their sense of belonging. Coaches build trust with teachers and let them know that they are not alone. This is often a challenging barrier with CS teachers who feel isolated, especially when they are not familiar with the content.

With support via coaching, teachers have the opportunity to grow in their profession leveraging the context of their classroom. Many of the APS teachers have taken lead on addressing bias in CS education in their own schools, such as the barriers that students face in terms of recruitment and achievement in CS education. Some have advocated for the removal of unnecessary prerequisites that were limiting historically underrepresented students in CS to enroll in an advanced CS course. During coaching sessions, teachers who progress beyond just building CS content knowledge, begin to understand that their role as a CS teacher can help establish equitable practices to provide more students the fair opportunity to study CS in their school. Over the project lifetime, more than 800 students enrolled in an AP CS course with 71% overall taking an AP CS Exam.
